awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Highly stable lipid bilayers on freestanding cytoskeleton-like membrane
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Luo, Xiaolong  
Proposal Number: 1553330 

Natural cell membranes are composed of a thin lipid bilayer (LB) that forms a continuous barrier around the cell, and abundant membrane proteins that play key functions of the cell and stabilize LB.  The cell membrane sits on a supporting intracellular matrix called cytoskeleton layer that defines cell shape and further stabilizes LB.  Ion channels and molecular receptors of membrane proteins on LB are the main targets of fundamental research and pharmaceutical drugs.  As such, model LBs have been the crucial platform to study transport and signaling processes of membrane proteins.  However, current model LBs suffer from notorious limitations including (1) short LB lifetime, (2) fluidic and/or electrical inaccessibility to both sides of the membranes, and (3) lack of the rich constituents of natural cell membrane.  Addressing these limitations of model LB systems should significantly expedite both fundamental biological studies and pharmaceutical drug screenings. 

This proposal outlines a five-year program of integrated research and educational activities focusing on the development of highly stable lipid bilayers (HSLB) in microfluidic networks.  The investigator proposes to fabricate LB on a freestanding, semi-permeable and mechanically robust biopolymer membrane, the first time such a configuration being pursued.  The work will assess the hypothesis that the supporting membrane can serve as a model cytoskeleton layer for the lipid bilayer with high stability that presents in natural cell membranes. The fabricated HSLB will be characterized and compared with current model LBs, applied to study ion channel activities and the virus-cell membrane fusion process, and scaled up for other research and industrial users.  Compared to current suspended and supported LBs, the developed HSLB system will provide long-term stability, better replication of cell membranes and ease of scaling-up, as well as enabling simultaneous fluidic, electrical and optical measurements and manipulations.  When fully established, the HSLB platform can be a game-changer for studying fundamental membrane biology and identifying membrane-associated novel drug targets, which are greatly limited by the current model LB systems.  Besides bioengineers developing microfluidic and Lab-on-a-Chip devices, this research will be of interest to scientists studying biopolymer materials and membrane protein activities, industrial researchers investigating drug targets and high throughput screening, and educators teaching biomaterials and biomicrosystems.

por.por_cntn:
This project integrates research and education for the principal investigator and research team focusing on the development of highly stable lipid bilayers (HSLB) and educating students with cohesive laboratory experience and interdisciplinary perspective. The HSLB was tethered onto a cytoskeleton-like biopolymer membrane prefabricated on Teflon partition films, ensuring the integrity and functionality of lipid bilayer. We have successfully fabricated HSLB with long-term stability of up to a couple months for the first time, and incorporated onto HSLB various transmembrane proteins including gramicidin A, protective antigen PA63, lethal factors of anthrax toxin, and alpha-hemolysin. Ion channel activities and peptide transport events were recorded following the transmembrane channel formation. The research delivers to the related community a novel lipid bilayer platform with extraordinary stability that can greatly facilitates the investigations of cellular structures and processes to elucidate fundamental cellular mechanisms. The novel platform has the potential to be applied to the pharmaceutical industry for screening and identifying targets of pharmaceutical drugs. The research has also advanced the understanding of unique properties of the chitosan, an enabling biomaterial to form extraordinarily robust membrane structures in microfluidic network with the potential to be scaled up. Extraordinary strong birefringence signals, an indication of molecular alignment level and crystalline structure, were observed from the flow-assembled or electrofabricated chitosan membranes in microfluidic networks. We have innovated the biofabrication of freestanding membranes with electrical signals with electrodes at the fabrication sites, a new manufacture paradigm with the potential to be scaled up. The knowledge gained will be applicable to a variety of biological studies and drug discoveryThis research is of interest to scientists studying biopolymer materials and membrane proteins, industrial researchers investigating drug targets and high throughput screening, and educators teaching biomaterials and biomicrosystems. In long term, the HSLB platform may contribute to improving public health by accelerating novel drug discovery. The research program has provides the support for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students the learning and training experience on an interdisciplinary topic, and has prepared them with needed skills and creativity in future career or advanced graduate studies.
